title: Embedded Object Wound
summary: Emergency care for wounds with embedded objects like glass, metal, or wood that should not be removed by first aiders.

steps.title: Do Not Remove the Object
steps.description: Leave the embedded object in place. Removing it may cause severe bleeding or further damage. The object may be plugging damaged blood vessels. Call 911 immediately for professional removal.

steps.title: Control Bleeding Around Object
steps.description: Apply direct pressure around the embedded object, not on it. Use sterile gauze or clean cloths to apply firm pressure on either side of the object to control bleeding.

steps.title: Stabilize the Object
steps.description: Place bulky dressings or clean cloths around the object to support and stabilize it. Build up padding around the object to the same height as the object to prevent movement.

steps.title: Secure the Dressing
steps.description: Use bandages or tape to secure the padding in place without putting pressure on the object. Create a 'doughnut' ring of bandaging around the object if needed. Ensure the object cannot move.

steps.title: Monitor for Shock
steps.description: Have the person lie still in a comfortable position. If no spinal injury is suspected, elevate their legs. Cover with a blanket to maintain body temperature. Monitor breathing and consciousness.

steps.title: Reassure and Wait for Help
steps.description: Keep the person calm and still to prevent further injury. Do not give food or water in case surgery is needed. Document the time of injury and type of object if known for medical personnel.

warnings: Never attempt to remove an embedded object
Do not probe or explore the wound
Avoid direct pressure on the embedded object
Movement may cause the object to cause more damage internally
whenToSeekHelp: Always seek immediate emergency medical help for embedded objects
This is a 911 emergency - do not attempt to transport yourself
Professional medical removal is required to prevent further injury
preventionTips: Wear safety glasses when working with tools or machinery
Keep work areas clean and free of debris
Use proper protective equipment for the task
Be aware of your surroundings to avoid trips and falls onto sharp objects
